learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate an understanding of key literature, principles and practices relating to the criminology and criminal justice target topic areas explored in this course (e.g. restorative justice, cybercrime and security, and financial crime investigation).
Understand the professional practice skills which can facilitate effective performance outcomes in the target topic areas.
Develop planning strategies incorporating learned principles and practices for relevant target topic area.
Understand the political, social, institutional, ethical, cultural and legal contexts that shape professional practice for each target topic area.
Problem-solve by working in collaborative teams and applying course concepts

assessments.assessment_title: Restorative Justice Practical: Conference Preparation, Facilitation and Reflection
assessments.due_date:
23/03/2026 2:00 pm

  1. Restorative justice conference (in-person practical; 20 points) will take place in class at a rostered time. Please attend class with your co-facilitator at the rostered time only.
  2. Post Conference Reflection (300 words; 10 points) to be submitted via Turnitin by 2PM.
assessments.task_description:
You are provided with an offence scenario including ‘referral and intake information’ for a restorative justice conference. This includes: an overview of the offence; information on relevant parties; information regarding harm; and information on potential outcomes.

For the restorative justice series assessment, you will have the opportunity to apply learning through an in-person practical completed in pairs (seating plan and facilitating the offender's account giving in a mock restorative justice conference) and post practical reflection. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard.

1.    Restorative justice conference (in-person practical; 20 points)

You will work in pairs to set up and facilitate the opening stage of a restorative justice conference (approx 10 minutes practical). You and a co-facilitator will demonstrate competence in two key areas: Establish a restorative justice seating arrangement and co-facilitate the Account Giving stage (offender only).

2.     Post Conference Reflection (300 words; 10 points)

Submit a post practical reflection via Turnitin on how your seating arrangement and facilitation approach aligned to restorative justice principles and practices, including areas of strength/improvement.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT):

Practical: You will be able to bring 1 single sided sheet/page of planning notes for your mock conference that summarises relevant referral and intake information and question prompts. Successful completion of your practical will require you to consider your own application of restorative justice principles and practices to the scenario. Therefore, artificial intelligence will unlikely provide relevant support and guidance.

Reflection: Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies to improve grammar and sentence structure in your reflection, successful completion of your reflection will require you to consider your own decisions and facilitation in the practical. Therefore, artificial intelligence will unlikely provide relevant support and guidance.

A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Restorative justice conference (in-person practical; 20 points) is an in-person, in-class assessment - please attend class with your co-facilitator at the rostered time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment tests your ability to translate cybercrime concepts into practical applications. You will respond to scenario-based prompts using a worksheet format (600 words +/- 10%).

Your responses must:

·        Demonstrate critical understanding of the Cybercrime and Security series content

·        Apply specific examples and evidence from class materials and literature

·        Translate technical and behavioural concepts into clear explanations suitable for non-technical audiences

·        Connect theory to practice with applicable insights

Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT): Do not upload the assessment scenario, artefacts or template into AI and MT systems as these have been developed with industry. This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% (15% Interview Plan & In-class Interview; 15% Mock Court Summation); </dd>
assessments.due_date:
Interview Plan 11/05/2026 2:00 pm

The Interviews will be conducted as a group in class at an allocated time in Week 11. Submit your Interview Plan via the Turnitin link provided by the due time.

The Mock Court summation will be conducted in UQ Sir Harry Gibbs Mock Court (next to UQ's Law Library) as a group at an allocated time in Week 13.
assessments.task_description:
Industry experts have been significantly involved in the development of the Financial Crime Investigation Series seminar content, activities and assessments. Students will be assigned to groups/financial investigation teams. Within a team, you will have opportunities to engage directly with industry representatives as you progress your group financial crime investigation. Engagement with course content and participation in financial investigation group activities is strongly recommended due to the integration of this content/activities within the final assessment. The Financial Crime Investigation will include two progressive learning group activities (Interview Plan with Interviews (15%), and Court Summation (15%)) to assess, analyse and collect evidence needed to complete the group Investigation Report. The completion of the financial crime learning activities will significantly inform this assessment and help your group to finalise the final report.

Each assessment will be conducted and submitted as a group. Without a previously approved extension, no marks are given to individual students and/or whole groups who do not conduct their interview plan/interviews or mock court summation on the due date. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard.

Use of AI: This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
8/06/2026 2:00 pm

Buddycheck: This assessment includes a Buddycheck. Each team member will complete a Buddycheck form by the due date which will provide an opportunity to reflect on the contribution each member of the team has made to the WHOLE group project. The Buddycheck form may be used to adjust marks according to contribution.
assessments.task_description:
The final assessment for the financial crime series is a Financial Crime Investigation Report (2,500 words). Students will be assigned to groups/financial investigation teams. Within teams, you will be asked to lead a component of the financial investigation report, integrating course content and activities. Effective teamwork strategies will be essential to inform the best overall investigative outcome. The Financial Crime Investigation Report is an opportunities for you to apply course content and learnings from criminology and criminal justice experts. To complete this report, you will be given a detailed report template. This report will include an executive summary, terms of reference, the investigations undertaken, conclusions, and reflections made from the investigation. This report will build upon in-class learning from industry experts and previous assessments. Further task details and requirements (including relevant marking criteria) can be found in the relevant Assessment folder on Blackboard.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT): Do not upload the assessment scenario, evidence/financial documents or template into AI and MT systems as these have been developed with industry. This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub. Students are required to provide an AI/MT declaration with this assignment.

Buddycheck: This assessment includes a Buddycheck. Each team member will complete a Buddycheck form by the due date which will provide an opportunity to reflect on the contribution each member of the team has made to the WHOLE group project. The Buddycheck form may be used to adjust marks according to contribution.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
